One shall say/another shall call/another shall subscribe. These three are not opposed to each other; they are not in different camps. Instead, Isaiah is showing three different ways that people appropriately declare their allegiance to the true God.

I am the Lord's. Those who partake of the water (44:3) will become part of Jehovah's spiritual family and accept his covenants (subscribe with his hand).

call himself by the name of Jacob. Those who partake of the water (44:3) will become members of the house of Israel. This phrase parallels "surname himself by the name of Israel" (44:5).

subscribe with his hand. The upraised hand, both anciently and today, represents one's taking the name of the Lord upon himself by covenant. It is frequently connected to ordinances, such as baptism and those performed in the temple. The righteous will "write (subscribe) on their hand" the phrase "the Lord's" as a constant reminder that they belong to him (NIV, RSV, JB, NEB). This writing is not literal but symbolic, pointing to sacred ordinances, where we pledge with the hand.

surname himself by the name of Israel. Those who accept the gospel and receive the gift of the Spirit become the "seed of Abraham" and members of the house of Israel.
